data.title: there is NO Scrolling Bar in the Integrated Terminal Panel
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X EI Capitan 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In a word, there is NO Scrolling Bar in the Integrated Terminal Panel, and I can't scroll view up to top to review more information.
2. Detail:
   In the **Integrated Terminal Panel**, execute `dotnet run` command, then visit `http://localhost:5000/api/values/5` in the Chrome browser, response 500 status code(_I leave an error in my codes purposely, so as to generate more information_) from server side. Back to VSCode, in the Integrated Terminal Panel output information more than shown at Panel's Height, but **MISSING the Scrolling Bar** in the panel, result in failing to scroll view up to review entire exception information. At present, only via resizing the height of Integrated Terminal Panel for looking more output info up.

data.title: Gutter customization
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

People asked for this feature when they request for git blame info #2248. Now I found we are relying on this as well when implementing Vim's relative line numbers.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/876920/17011009/f0f23d9e-4f3b-11e6-9eae-7bb5da4bd65a.png)

See image above, you can set relative line numbers in Vim then you can easily know how many lines up or down you want to operate, instead of calculating the line numbers yourself. Currently it's not possible.

cc @kieferrm

data.title: Test: Provide ability to expose/share settings from settings.json to the launch.json
data.body:
Test plan for #8784 
#### Operating Systems
- [x] Linux @jrieken
- [x] Mac @chrmarti
- [x] Windows @ramya-rao-a
#### What to Test?

Summary: Ensure variables defined in:
- launch.json are properly parsed before passing them to the debugger
- tasks.json are properly parsed before passing them into the task being executed.

Variables such as:
- ${workspaceRoot}  
- ${env...} (environment variables)
- $(config...) ****(settings - note: this is what has been added in the PR #8784)****

One can now make reference to settings defined in settings.json from within the launch.json and tasks.json file. 

For instance the value "**${config.editor.fontFamily}**" defined in launch.json or tasks.json, will be replaced with the actual value **"Menlo, Monaco, 'Courier New', monospace"** when launching the debugger or executing a task (as is done today with ${workspaceRoot}).
#### Sample Test 1 (Node.js Debugger)
- Configure the launch.json file as follows:

``` json
{
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "args": ["${workspaceRoot}", "${config.editor.fontFamily}"],
```
- When debugging confirm the actual font Family (as defined in settings.json) value is passed into the program
#### Sample Test 2 (Task)
- Create a tasks.json file as follows

``` json
{
    "command": "echo",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["Hello World", "${workspaceRoot}", "${config.editor.fontFamily}"],
    "showOutput": "always"
}
```
- Run the above task and confirm the actual font Family (as defined in settings.json) value is passed into the task

data.title: Cannot debug Node.js applications in development environment
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Master Branch
- OS Version: OS X Elcapitan 10.11.6 (15G31)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. **Clone the master branch**
2. Run ./scripts/npm.sh install
3. Open a folder with the javascript named test.js with a simple console.log statement
4. Try to debug using the node debugger
5. The following launch.json file gets created:

``` json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": []
}
```
1. Updated launch.json as follows:

``` json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Launch",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/test.js",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "preLaunchTask": null,
            "runtimeExecutable": null,
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--nolazy"
            ],
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "development"
            },
            "externalConsole": false,
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null
        },
```
1. Start debugging and then you get the following error:

```
No extension installed for 'node' debugging.
```

Is this the expected behaviour? 
I was under the impression that built in extensions such as the node debugger would work out of the box.

Here's the output in the console window:

```
[56660:0721/120327:INFO:CONSOLE(222)] "%c[Extension Host] %cdebugger listening on port 5870", source: file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/workbench/services/thread/electron-browser/threadService.js (222)
[56660:0721/120338:INFO:CONSOLE(80)] "No extension installed for 'node' debugging.: Error: No extension installed for 'node' debugging.
    at Object.create (file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/base/common/errors.js:317:22)
    at file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugService.js:557:67
    at ErrorPromise_then [as then] (file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:1436:50)
    at file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugService.js:541:20
    at CompletePromise_ctor.CompletePromise_then [as then] (file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:1566:49)
    at DebugService.doCreateSession (file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugService.js:480:16)
    at _this.runPreLaunchTask.then._this.messageService.show.message (file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugService.js:450:38)
    at CompletePromise_ctor.CompletePromise_then [as then] (file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:1566:49)
    at file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugService.js:445:76
    at CompletePromise_then [as then] (file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:1566:49)", source: file:////<VscodePath>/out/vs/workbench/services/message/browser/messageService.js (80)
```

data.title: Opening a single file should be almost be as quick as opening up in a basic text editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

I've noticed that the start up times for VS code are slowing down with each iteration of VS Code. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open windows explorer and browser to a file which you want to edit (eg. text, markdown, html, javascript file)
2. Open vs code via explorers file context menu using the "Open in VS Code" option
3. Initial load time to the point where you can viewing and editing the file should be as close to opening up in something similar to notepad.

Expectations:
- Intellisense or syntax highlighting doesn't need to be loaded straight away, it could be deferred until the editor has finished the initial load.
- This should not apply to loading up whole directories/projects/solutions as the individual users task isn't a quick edit or view.

I'm hoping by raising this issue that performance benchmarks for VS code initial load times will be established for future releases.

data.title: VSCode only waits for 1 second on disconnect
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows/Mac

Steps to Reproduce:
This issue can be reproduced with the sample and repro steps provided by @jeffschwMSFT in issue https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/issues/352 

Refer: https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/issues/582 for the related bug in omnisharp-vscode. 

Issue: 
VSCode only waits for 1 second for the debugger to disconnect. When there is a long running operation on debugger (such as expanding a long array on watch window) the debugger is still holding on to the dll/pdbs. VSCode spawns build tasks, which eventually fails because of file locks and resulting project in a bad state (The files are zero sized on mac, missing dlls on windows etc). 

code: workbench/parts/debug/node/rawDebugSession.ts 
function: disconnect

Potential fixes
1. Wait for infinite amount of time for the debugger to exit. 
2. Provide a different event which can forcefully terminate the debugger on a certain timeout.

data.title: Visual studio does not start AS a normal user if it was started as a root user for first time
data.body:
- VSCode Version:Version 1.3.1
- OS Version: Any Linux(RHEL in my case ) machine

Steps to Reproduce:
0 . Login as root user to a linux machine ( at "login screen" choose username as root and give the root password)
1.  Download the VS Code RPM
2. Install it ( rpm -ivh, in my case )  
3. After installation is done, run the command, "code" on terminal
4. We see a message,  _I_t is recommended to start vscode as a normal user. To run as root, you must specify an alternate user data directory with the --user-data-dir argument.__

4.1 -- To be able to run, we give something like code --user-data-dir=/home/troll_user/troll_folder

4.2 -- It runs , do some code editing, save some file.
1.  Now change user via terminal, su trolluser 

5.1 Try typing code on terminal now.
1. We get an error, 
           _bash: /root/.bashrc: Permission denied_

---

How to get code working as a normal user now.

Notice, I have not logged off, I logged in as root user to being with, ran _code_, then did su trolluser, then cannot run _code_

data.title: #55: Add performance test for QuickOpen
Dynamic args for debug task
data.body:
It would be nice if one could define task with option `dynamicArgs: true` in `launch.json` (or something similar) that when starting debugger for the task - it would prompt user with text box to provide arguments that would be passed to the script (similar how current static `args` option works)

Use case: Ability to easily debug some cli tasks that can start with different arguments on command line

Right now one need to go to launch.json and edit arguments or duplicate configurations to handle different arguments

data.title: getLinesViewportData api in verticalObjects is returning range where start line and end line is not visible
data.body:
verticalObjects.getLinesViewportData() returns the view lines data those are not visible in the current view port. 
- When a line is wrapped and is not visible completely on the top, Some times start line number value is the wrapped line # which is not visible.
- End line number is always one number greater than visible end line

As a result, In Vim:
- `H` and `L` commands seem to go to outside the view.

data.title: On Mac french keyboard layout the backslash '/' blocked by shortcuts
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version:  OS X EI Captitan version 10.11.5

For a mac french keyboard (azerty layout), the general way to make a backslash '\' is by shift+alt+:

However, this combination is overwrited by vscode shortcut:

```
{ "key": "shift+alt+.",           "command": "closeTag.closeHTMLTagInPlace",
                                     "when": "editorTextFocus" },
```

which says

```
For your current keyboard layout press 
:
Key or key sequence (separated by space)
```

That makes it impossible to type '\', even after I changed the default shortcuts combination.

Any idea?

data.title: (Duplicate) Request: Reveal in tree (In Open Editors context menu)
data.body:
Hi there, I believe this has not been requested yet after my search.

What I want is to be able to right click on files in the `Open Editors` and have an option `Reveal in tree` which would find the file in vscode tree. That option could be listed right before `Reveal in explorer`.

That feature would be awesome as I am currently working with an angular project. I sometimes open a `controller` and find myself adding a depedency which is then needed in the `component`, so an option like that could save time in a big project.

data.title: Visual Studio Code should update itself silently

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I think automatic update is great, but I think some people just want the thing updated automatically without being asked.   There can be notification that indicates that it's changed and what's new.   But I think we should follow the Chrome model and just update it.

Why?

Think of it as software running on the web.   When I go to cnn.com, I'm not notified that there's a new version of the back-end software that I might be running.   So why / when should I care if the front-end software has updated?

Sometimes you care -- such as low-bandwidth situations.   But that doesn't mean everyone cares.   Some of us, dare I say, a large majority of people, just want the latest stuff all the time.

Thank you for listening.
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. 
2.

data.title: Fix minor spelling mistake in comment: Iff > If
data.body: Fix minor spelling mistake in comment: Iff > If

data.title: Support variable paging (aka chunked arrays)
data.body:
Currently large data structures (Array, Map, Set) are broken into "chunks" in the debug adapter. Potentially this results in lots of duplication.

This feature request asks for doing this in the VS Code debugger UI once and for all.

An implementation sketch:
- if a variable, scope, or evaluate result has a `totalCount` attribute, check whether its value is larger than some (configurable) threshold.
- if yes then insert intermediate variable nodes between the parent and the children so that every node covers the range 0..threshold-1. Show this range as the label of the intermediate node.
- if an intermediate node is expanded, fetch only the corresponding range of children via the `variablesRequest` and the new `start` and `count` arguments.
- return a value of true for the `supportsVariablePaging` capability to indicate that the UI handles variable paging.

The corresponding protocol addition:  https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-debugadapter-node/issues/31

data.title: Implement lineViewTop, lineViewBottom, lineViewCenter
data.body:
Implement 
- lineViewTop: go to the Nth line in the window, on the first non-blank
- lineViewBottom: go to the Nth line from the bottom, on the first non-blank
- lineViewCenter: go to the middle line in the window, on the first non-blank
